However, I really urge you to travel the world and you'll return to the UK feeling prouder than ever that we are truly a multicultural country and one that doesn't rest on its laurels, but works hard to ensure the country works for everyone.

Stephanie, I don't think it's about saying everyone is a racist. I think there's a real difference between intention and impact and whether we intend to be racist or intolerant is irrelevant, if the impact is that our behaviours affect people in our country in a negative way, then we need to call it out for what it is. That's not saying that everyone is a racist, but we are allowing ourselves to normalise hate crime and as such there has been a tangible increase.

And I don't buy into the argument that just because other countries are 'worse' that we should not hold ourselves accountable. If we pride ourselves on being a melting pot, then we need to evidence that with how we behave - especially to those in our society who are the most risk of harm.

I'm not hating on the people in this country. I'm hating on our government, they are the ones making the decisions that are allowing this to happen. But that said, our government also act with a mandate. They were voted in and they are not being challenged enough by the people in this country. I can only assume that it's because people are happy to accept the mistreatment of others without question, as long as it doesn't come close to home.
Though true - the west has tried to lead by example and ought to continue doing so imo

Trying to think why I disliked the comment so much "epitome of xenophobic intolerance" seemed like the typical extreme reaction in politics or discussions, there is no center ground any more, no give and take. It is all just take. Or maybe the truth that hate is increasing and less hidden due to the confrontational nature of politics or facebook, where people feel they can say whatever. Or maybe it was the comment "our government is doing everything within their power to create a two tiered class system - the very rich and the very poor." Because that comment is true, but to me it seems to ignore that different governments have been doing this in my lifetime, not just this one, not just after the Brexit vote. That people are only concerned now, with the poor because the middle classes are suffering now, now suddenly being and helping poor is an issue to them? Where have they been for the last 30 years, when the poor marched for their jobs, were promised new training and light industries. All for politics and the meida to switch focus on London again and London politics. But maybe I am at fault, I am the one projecting. Because on paper it is a comment I could easily have said. (not using the word epitome though).

So your issue isn't a semantic one, it's to do with fact that those who have had historically  privileged positions are only now talking about things that affect them? Also, I'm happy to justify the use of 'epitome' - it just means perfect example of. You can have a number of synonyms that amount the same thing. We are a perfect example of a country that has veered towards intolerance and xenophobia. Being an epitome of something doesn't mean we are the only country to behave that way.

Vicki Lamb it is not the perfect example though is it? My mums home country of Turkey can be considered in my view a perfect example. The UK is nowhere near a perfect example of xenophobia intolerance. Maybe its because I come from a multicultural family and my wife is Chinese and I have travelled far and wide, but we are not the perfect example. Although you have developed you’re meaning to say we are an example of a country veering or on a sliding scale towards intolerance and exnopboia, I still find it unfair but I can understand that point of view and agree with the expanded sentiment, but not that opening phrase which just goes to the extreme. But we are not going to agree on this. So good day and thanks for your reply.

Lance Freeman MA the thing is that each EU country us free to control its own affairs.

Decisions that are implemented are made by the MEP parliamentarians which we elect directly and finally by the ministers in our own sovereign cabinets representing us in the council.

All decisions are reviewed by each sovereign parliament before getting a final vote allowing representatives to edit whatever they not agree with.

In major issues each member state had the right to veto any legislation or guideline that they may feel is contrary to its country.

Freedom of movement is a great thing!! And trust me, it's not as free as the Leave campaign made it out to be. Its the incompetence of the British Gov and the Home Office that didn't implement the immigration restrictive regulations the EU allows. In Germany you CAN'T stay longer than 3 months if you haven't found a job. You are not entitled to free healthcare or any benefits or allowances unless you have worked a number of months or years and even then they are limited for none German citizens. Also many jobs in Germany set standards that applicants have to meet. You need certain level of German language knowledge etc, indirectly forcing unwanted immigration out without breaking the EU freedom of movement rules. Why weren't these regulations implemented here?!

In many EU countries it is 3 months. That the UK decided not to implement Directive 2004/38/EC is the fault of our government, not the EU!

For those unfamiliar with Directive 2004/38/EC it states the following: "For the first three months, every EU citizen has the right to reside on the territory of another EU country without any conditions or formalities. For longer periods, the host Member State may require a citizen to register his or her presence within a reasonable and non-discriminatory period of time. Migrant workers’ right to reside for more than three months remains subject to certain conditions, which vary depending on the citizen’s status: for EU citizens who are not workers or self-employed, the right of residence depends on their having sufficient resources not to become a burden on the host Member State’s social assistance system, and having sickness insurance. EU citizens acquire the right of permanent residence in the host Member State after a period of five years of uninterrupted legal residence."

A cap on immigration from third world countries will be imposed despite cabinet concern that the policy could harm the economy. The school secretary and university minister have raised concerns that the cap could deprive the economy of skilled labour. Baroness Valentine said that the word cap is a very negative word to put out to the global market place.

While EU nationals generally have full access to all social benefits and housing on the same basis as British citizens (those from the central and eastern European accession states have to be in registered employment for a year first), the visas of non-EU economic migrants are issued subject to the condition of 'no recourse to public funds'. That means no welfare benefits and no public housing. Only schools and NHS treatment are freely available to non-EU economic migrant workers and their families - but the small numbers involved mean that the impact is negligible. And in terms of social justice, why shouldn't migrant workers be entitled to public services funded by their taxes and national insurance contributions? 

This is not a race or religion issue for me, as an example a doctor from the sub-continent, might well have similar medical or surgical skills to one from within the EU, but the former would be likely to have better command of the English language, and therefore more likely to be able to respond appropriately. 

There is a strong connection between economic success and the contribution of immigrants. A study suggests that a 1% population increase through migration triggers 1.5% increase in GDP. Immigrants are also human beings with social, emotional and spiritual needs and demands. They are not just economics for the economic prosperity of the British society. 

Migration is good for economy and business. Migrants pay more taxes than they use in public services.
